### How Safety Limits Are Set

Regulatory bodies such as the **International Commission on Non‑Ionizing Radiation Protection (ICNIRP)** and the **Federal Communications Commission (FCC)** establish exposure limits for radio‑frequency (RF) fields based on two key concepts:

| Concept | What It Means | Typical Limit for 5 GHz (the band most often used for 5G) |
|---------|----------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|
| **Specific Absorption Rate (SAR)** | The rate at which the body absorbs RF energy, measured in watts per kilogram (W/kg). | 2 W/kg averaged over 10 g of tissue (U.S.) / 4 W/kg averaged over 10 g (EU) |
| **Power‑Flux Density (PFD)** | The power crossing a unit area, measured in watts per square meter (W/m²). This is the metric most relevant for people standing near an antenna. | 10 W/m² for frequencies between 2 GHz and 300 GHz (ICNIRP) |

These limits are **far below** the levels that would cause any measurable heating of tissue. The limits include a large safety margin (typically a factor of 50–100) compared with the minimum exposure that would produce a measurable temperature rise of 0.1 °C in the skin.

---

### Typical Exposure Near a 5G Small Cell

A **5G “small cell”** is a low‑power base station mounted on lamp posts, building façades, or street furniture. Its purpose is to provide dense coverage in urban environments while keeping transmit power modest.

| Parameter | Typical Value (illustrative) |
|-----------|------------------------------|
| **Maximum Effective Isotropic Radiated Power (EIRP)** | 30 dBm (≈ 1 W) for the mmWave (24 – 28 GHz) band; up to 43 dBm (≈ 20 W) for sub‑6 GHz bands (varies by country) |
| **Antenna gain** | 10 – 15 dBi (sub‑6 GHz) ; 20 – 25 dBi (mmWave) |
| **Resulting PFD at 1 m distance** | ≈ 0.2 – 0.5 W/m² (sub‑6 GHz) ; ≈ 0.05 – 0.2 W/m² (mmWave) |
| **PFD at 5 m distance** | ≈ 0.01 – 0.04 W/m² (sub‑6 GHz) ; ≈ 0.002 – 0.01 W/m² (mmWave) |
| **PFD at 10 m distance** | ≈ 0.005 – 0.02 W/m² (sub‑6 GHz) ; ≈ 0.001 – 0.005 W/m² (mmWave) |

> **Key point:** Even right at the base of a small cell (≈ 1 m), the measured power‑flux density is typically **one to two orders of magnitude below** the ICNIRP limit of 10 W/m². At ordinary walking distances (5 – 10 m), the exposure drops to **well under 0.1 W/m²**, i.e., **< 1 %** of the safety threshold.

---

### Why the Beam Doesn’t Penetrate Deeply

- **Frequency matters:** The higher‑frequency mmWave bands (24‑28 GHz) are absorbed within the first **0.5–2 mm** of skin. They are essentially surface heating, which is why the limits are set on power‑flux density rather than SAR for those bands.
- **Beamforming is directional:** Small cells use phased‑array antennas that steer narrow beams toward devices that are actively communicating. When no device is present, the radiated power defaults to a very low “idle” level, further reducing ambient exposure.
